Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is the second stage of a large project to examine social and linguistic factors of language variation in the West Virginia region of Appalachia. The primary goal is to determine the dialect's current status, including its regional affiliations, its relative degree of vernacularity, its sociolinguistic divisions, and its directions of change. From the research accomplished to date, it is clear that many of the traditional features of English in Appalachia are fading from WV, although some remain under the radar of social awareness. The current proposal involves computer-assisted acoustic phonetic analysis in order to enhance the description the sounds of Appalachia. Specifically, research will analyze the progression of vowel shifts (e.g."beyd" for "bed"), vowel mergers (e.g. pronouncing "pin/pen" the same), and consonantal changes (e.g. pronouncing "which/witch" the same). An additional facet of this research is the examination of rural America. Rural areas in the United States are changing, and the sociolinguistic patterns discovered will illuminate those changes.

This proposal emanates from a core EPSCoR state, and it provides worthwhile educational and community benefits. This project integrates research and education by advancing discovery and understanding for the research assistants while at the same time promoting better language awareness for teachers in K-12 schools and better training for future teachers. The research team is currently creating an interactive website that will provide an educational environment for learning about dialect history, language change, synchronic variation, and dialect attitudes. The results from this proposal will be incorporated into this educational site. The broader impacts from this project also include a more accurate description of Appalachian English, a variety much maligned in the 20th century.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the fine details of sounds in Appalachian Englishes is crucial to understanding how languages are transformed by everyday language. The findings of scientific sound analysis also can be used in dialect awareness programs to help combat the negative connotations that are typically associated with the dialects of Appalachia. Within the work of this grant, research was conducted on consonant and vowel variation for native Appalachians born between the 1920 and 1990. The research focused on some socially relevant dialect features in modern Appalachia along with others less well-known in the region, including vowel differences, the merger of words like witch~which and pin~pen, changing a z to an s in words like bugs, and the loss of h in words like huge.


As part of the research efforts of the West Virginia Dialect Project (WVDP), an undergraduate sociolinguistic research lab at West Virginia University, we work to determine the current status and directions of change for English in Appalachia, including the regional affiliations, the degrees of vernacularity, and the social divisions in dialects. This research has led to numerous public outreach events, presentations, and reports that aim to educate the public on dialects and language variation and to destigmatize vernacular Appalachian features.


Our research shows that many of the traditional features of English in Appalachia faded from WV, although some remain under the radar of social awareness. Because people use vowels to make fine-grained distinctions and mark social differences, the most finely-grained and socially important language variation patterns in modern Appalachia are the ongoing changes to vowel systems. Another facet of this research is the examination of how changes to rural Appalachia are affecting the directions of language change. Rural areas in the United States transformed in the 20th century and  continue to evolve today. Our findings show that the language patterns of rural Americans reflect those changes.


Since 1998, The WVDP has conducted 225 interviews with native Appalachians. This grant helped the WVDP conduct a close study of the sound patterns in the core corpus of these interviews. In addition to that analysis, in the last year of the grant, interviews were conducted with native Appalachians from born in the 1990s to provide evidence about dialect variation and language change at the end of the century. This grant has also led the WVDP to refine and develop research and training methods associated with linguistic research.


Beyond the public outreach efforts, the WVDP’s research efforts, through this grant, has provided invaluable training and scientific research experience for the undergraduate Research Assistants who worked with Dr. Kirk Hazen. These students have gone on to become teachers, professional writers, data analysts, and human resource experts.


Overall, the work from this grant employed acoustic phonetic analysis to enhance the description of language variation in the WV region of Appalachia. As a result of this NSF grant, English in Appalachia, one of the world’s best known varieties of English, now has several empirical studies of its sound patterns.
